I wasn't able to figure out whether I should be including a change in dbus/dbusconfiguration.cpp as I don't see how this new property is populated in the D-Bus interface.

https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/14766/ : SUCCESS

Patch Set 11:

> Patch Set 10:
> 
> I wasn't able to figure out whether I should be including a change in dbus/dbusconfiguration.cpp as I don't see how this new property is populated in the D-Bus interface.

There's two code paths for configuration here. You need to add it to both. There's a way to get the configuration from D-Bus, and a way to get the configuration from the JSON file directly. Take a look at the "dbus" subdirectory, that will show you an example of how it's done for all the other fields.
Uploaded patch set 12.

User approved, CI ok to start

> 
> There's two code paths for configuration here. You need to add it to both. There's a way to get the configuration from D-Bus, and a way to get the configuration from the JSON file directly. Take a look at the "dbus" subdirectory, that will show you an example of how it's done for all the other fields.

Following the example for failsafePercent for Dbus, I could only find the 2 lines at d/bus/dbusconfiguration.cpp (https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/search?p=2&q=failsafepercent) I have submitted a change that imitates it - please let me know if I'm missing something else (it's magic to me how that 2 lines would allow us to create the property in the dbus though - the code in there is quite complex to try to understand).

> > 
> > There's two code paths for configuration here. You need to add it to both. There's a way to get the configuration from D-Bus, and a way to get the configuration from the JSON file directly. Take a look at the "dbus" subdirectory, that will show you an example of how it's done for all the other fields.
> 
> Following the example for failsafePercent for Dbus, I could only find the 2 lines at d/bus/dbusconfiguration.cpp (https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/search?p=2&q=failsafepercent) I have submitted a change that imitates it - please let me know if I'm missing something else (it's magic to me how that 2 lines would allow us to create the property in the dbus though - the code in there is quite complex to try to understand).

The reason for it only being 2 lines is that the field "failSafePercent" already exists, and unfortunately, the capitalization isn't consistent at all with it, so a search that's case-sensitive doesn't find it all. Here's a better example:

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/search?q=minThermalOutput

Notice this field is used in many places. It's declared as a variable within a structure, then it's filled in from D-Bus, or alternatively, filled in from JSON directly.

Abandoned

not needed anymore

This suddenly makes ZoneFlags required on all configurations, which is going to break a lot of people (everyone with downstream patches, assuming you go through and fix all the upstream ones).  Are you sure you don't want to define something optional?  That seems relatively straightforward to do.

Also, this is generally not how we'd specify the dbus interface, we'd specify each feature as a field, not one bitfield squished together.  That makes the interface much more clear.

See comment on the next patchset though, I'm kinda wondering if this feature isnt't already covered by existing code.

I originally made it a separate boolean flag but talking to Josh, it seemed like this would allow us to easily add future flags.

Yes, unfortunately I didn't quite understand this part of the code and where / how we were setting this property in the D-Bus so I'm not surprised I did it wrong.

I'd much rather have it be a number, not just a boolean. The reason is, it will make future additions much easier, saving toil. Also, it will avoid a proliferation of boolean parameters.

And, a huge reason to want a more future-proof design is the extreme brittleness of D-Bus interfaces, that you were telling me about earlier, when I wanted to add the "Mutable" field to the Value interface, in dbus-sensors. If it's true that you can't make any changes to an interface after it has been used in code that's widespread, then it will be a real mess to have to invent a new interface for each boolean field that people might want to add. It will lead to a proliferation of interfaces, and each of them requires a separate D-Bus call to read, further slowing down the system. It would be so much easier just to grab all the bits at once.

> I'd much rather have it be a number, not just a boolean. The reason is, it will make future additions much easier, saving toil. Also, it will avoid a proliferation of boolean parameters.

We can store it however we like inside the daemon, but in terms of dbus, we don't do these flag parameters, nor do we do bool generally (unless it's brutally obvious what it is).  As a general rule, these would be enum types, which I think would alleviate your proliferation concerns.  If you'd like to see us do bitfields more (or ever), this patchset isn't the place to set that precedent, you would do it in phosphor-dbus-interfaces.

> 
> And, a huge reason to want a more future-proof design is the extreme brittleness of D-Bus interfaces, that you were telling me about earlier, 

It's code like this that makes dbus interfaces "brittle", which make changes to a single interface definition without updating everything else, or making the new interface optional, and now we have two definitions of what a Zone interface can be.

> when I wanted to add the "Mutable" field to the Value interface, in dbus-sensors. If it's true that you can't make any changes to an interface after it has been used in code that's widespread, then it will be a real mess to have to invent a new interface for each boolean field that people might want to add.

I'm not following this.  What you call "a real mess" is something we do all time time, mostly seamlessly.  New interfaces are easy to do, and optional, which we have pretty good processes for.  Also, we have made changes in widespread interfaces, your change wasn't the first change to the sensor Value interface, it just requires work.
Adding new fields to existing schemas, or changing the prototype of them, is something that we aren't very good at, which is what this patchset is doing currently.  In fact, the original dbus bindings we used couldn't even handle this kind of interface change in a backward compatible way.  Nowadays we know how to handle this kind of thing better, but it's still error prone.

> It will lead to a proliferation of interfaces, and each of them requires a separate D-Bus call to read,

I'm not sure where you got that information, but it's wrong, you can read all the dbus interfaces in a single GetManagedObjects call, like most daemons that care about performance tend to do.  Alternatively, GetAll, with an empty interface name will also grab you all the properties in a more error prone fashion, but in a way that only grabs you a single object.

> further slowing down the system. It would be so much easier just to grab all the bits at once.

Happy to debate what would be easier, but this patchset isn't the place to do it.  We should follow the current best practices for dbus interfaces.

You have valid points. How about this: Rename "ZoneFlags" to "Options" or "ZoneOptions". Instead of a number acting as a bitfield, make it an array of strings. The presence of a certain string in the array indicates that a particular option is enabled. This lets new options be arbitrarily added without having to redefine an interface that's already in use. It's also a lot cleaner-looking than a bitfield, which can rapidly become obscure and inelegant. Would this work better?

You should just add more optional keys to your dictionary. Generally instead of a bitfield you would just have definitions like "capMaxFailsafe": "true", or if that thing takes its own parameters you pass a dict to it.

I'm not really a big fan of that either;  The whole point of dbus is doing the exact opposite of what you're wanting, in that it's explicit, and ideally well documented what each param does, and each param is fixed.  Keep in mind, all of these parameters will need to be available to Redfish, and updated in entity-manager.  Redfish can't just push arbitrary values to REST, as we're held to a schema there, so the APIs will need to be well defined, and you'll need to update three components every time you add a parameter anyway (This repo to add the feature, entity-manager to document and move all the platforms forward that already have configs, and Redfish to add the parameter to the PID rest API).

I don't really see moving to any sort of dict or flags API fixing that.

Trying to remember + revive this discussion as we try to upstream this patch.

Initial proposal I had was to just create a build flag / define that we can set at build time as we believe this is more of a bugfix than a feature (summary in code being: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/+/41810/17/pid/fancontroller.cpp) where we believe at failsafe, we should be setting the fan speed to failsafe RPM rather than a calculated value that may be higher than failsafe.

Since other platforms and companies may want the original (old) behavior, I thought a build flag / define would be the "easiest" solution. If I remember correctly, Josh was not a fan of this idea because we do not have any build flags in this repo yet, and wanted to keep it that way.

Since a build flag would not require a D-Bus property to be added, I feel this is the easiest / simplest way, but please let me know if this is still a bad idea.

I agree that a compile-time build flag should be used. The odds of it needing to change at runtime are essentially zero. Ed mentioned how difficult/impossible it is to change an established D-Bus interface, so we should not do that.

I don't remember having any objection to a build flag earlier (if I did, sorry about that). Let's go with a build flag.
Thanks Josh! Let me create a patch to do that. Will keep this open in case Ed had any other ideas / objections while I make the patch
Since https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/+/41810 is abandoned, should this also be abandoned?
Yes, this can be abandoned.
